Emily Gielnik is redefining success and herself

The highs and lows of football not only define someone as football, but also as person. Westfield Matildas’ forward Emily Gielnik embodies that notion.

With the world firmly placed on pause during the period of COVID-19, restrictions have shut down the normality of life around the globe.

Being in lockdown with your thoughts to keep you company can be in equal parts challenging and invigorating. For Emily Gielnik, isolation has been a time for reflection and consideration.

“I saw the light; you communicate more and you get to look at life from a different perspective,” she said from her apartment in Munich, Germany.

“I was actually feeling quite fortunate. Even though football is my job, my career, my life and it’s hard to go from doing what you love to not be doing it at all, but watching the news really put things into perspective for me.”

A TIME OF REFLECTION

After returning from the AFC Women’s Olympic Qualifiers, Emily Gielnik and her Bayern Munich teammates soon found themselves returning to their homes as COVID-19 restrictions came into effect in Germany.

For the 28-year-old, the restrictions occurred at a fortuitous time with both her mum and partner on hand to ride out the opening weeks.

“It was nice to have her [Mum] here,” Gielnik said.

“[We were] just sharing some good quality time. There was definitely a lot of laughs and a lot of cooking happening!”



After years of intermittent separation, the time mother and daughter spent together away from reality was a blessing.

“When you go over to their [her parents] house and you see them on the weekend, it’s so rushed and you're not really there. You're replying to people and on social media. I feel like she was here, and I was actually engaging.”

“If we hadn’t been in quarantine, it would have been a lot different if she was here. I was at full time training and I would have only seen her a little bit in the morning and a little bit in the afternoon.”

FATHER & FRIEND

Emily Gielnik admits that her life story is much like her football story; a tale of a late bloomer.

Unlike many of her peers, with basketball and rugby being her first loves, Gielnik didn’t playing football until the age of twelve. Even then, it was after much encouragement on the part of the teenager to coax her parents to let her take to the pitch.

“It took a lot of persuading in terms of my Mum and her letting me play soccer because she thought it's such high injury sport - although I played rugby against boys so I can't comprehend it,” she laughed.

Gielnik made the switch from rugby to football and never looked back (Supplied: Emily Gielnik)

While her Mum may have been apprehensive about those first steps, Gielnik’s Dad was right beside her every step of the way.

“I had that Dad that was always taking me to every sporting event possible,” she remembered fondly.

“He would watch all my basketball games; all my football games and he was without a doubt that man that is running up and down the sidelines of the game and yelling at you to stop watching the play.”

Gielnik credits her father’s patience and support for pushing her to the next level. Criticism, no matter how constructive, can be a difficult to take on as a teenager. Looking back with the time and distance, Gielnik has no doubt his influence shaped her into the player she needed to be in order become a professional player.

“I always wanted to be pro one day,” she said “I didn't grow up with this those skills or that coaching, I just had my Dad,”

“I think he could sense that I wanted to get there so then he was criticising me, maybe at times he was criticising me too tough.”

He just wanted to make me better because maybe he could see that I could make it to the top and he knew I could be good.”

At the age of 15, Gielnik made the Queensland squad for the National Championships at Coffs Harbour but as her friends and teammates made their way into the Queensland Academy of Sport, Gielnik never received a letter.

Opportunities can pop up in the strangest of places and while on a school trip where she visited the Australian Institute of Sport, Gielnik got her chance to train with the Westfield Matildas. Her letter from QAS came shortly after.

That finally put Gielnik on the path she had wanted for so long. A season with the QAS resulted in the striker earning a contract the following year with a star studded Brisbane Roar outfit.

Gielnik settling into the Matildas (Photo Credit: Rachel Bach / By the White Line)

After a successful 2011/12 season with Roar, where she earned the moniker of ‘super sub’, Gielnik finally earned a call up to the Westfield Matildas.

Her first appearance for the Westfield Matildas came in Japan in 2012. While it might have been an ocean away, her father wasn’t far away from her thoughts. These days he is a fixture Westfield Matildas home matches and proudly boasts the number 15.

“He wears that jersey with pride…you can’t miss him!” Gielnik laughed.

“When I’m in the starting line-up whomever is next to me is like ‘oh my god Em, that’s your Dad’.”

“I'm actually playing for two people. Sometimes he lines up a shot and fully kicks like an air swing on the sideline. He's got like that as if he's kicked it. He's a part of the game, like he's a part of us.”

REDEFINING SUCCESS

In a scripted Disney production, realising a dream and playing for the Westfield Matildas should have been the beginning of a long and steady stint in the senior national team.

However, in real life, Gielnik’s ride was set to be a rollercoaster instead. That first run with the national team was followed by long periods away, and more frustrating periods of being close but not quite close enough.

2015 saw her omission from the FIFA Women’s World Cup and 2016 resulted in heartbreak after being a part of the 2016 Rio Olympic Games qualification campaign.

Each time, the Queenslander has dusted herself off – although it has not been without some soul searching and exploring different outlets for self fulfillment.



"After I got cut from the Olympics, I started to realise that I’ve got to do something that makes me happy now and I opened the gym [ShredEm Fitness],” she said.

“Everything just went so well, and I had never been so happy so of course my football just skyrocketed.”

“I was like obsessed with helping people. I was obsessed with helping someone from being so miserable and not comfortable at any other gyms and then they came and gave me a shot,” she said.

“I wasn't then putting so much pressure about making the Matildas squad or proving myself that stage I was like I got this gym now I'm just going to play W- League enjoy it and love it.”

Of course I was missing and craving the Matildas, but I stopped putting so much heavy pressure on myself thinking that that's all I wanted. I had the gym and so that created some happiness and some drive for me.”

Eventually the off the field success began to impact Gielnik’s success on it. A breakthrough 2017 Algarve Cup, a brilliant Westfield W-League season with Melbourne Victory in 2018/19 culminated in being named to her first major tournament squads for the 2018 AFC Women’s Asian Cup and FIFA Women’s World Cup 2019.

Finding her confidence and goal scoring touch for the Westfield Matildas saw big clubs around the world begin to take notice of the powerful forward.

After stints in the United States, Japan and Norway, Gielnik joined Frauen Bundesliga giants Bayern Munich.

“I heard from KK and Emily (Van Egmond), and people that have played in Germany, that their regiment was just craziness,” she said.

“For some reason I was longing for that environment.”



Moving halfway across the world with a language barrier was a welcome challenge for Gielnik but the move has also tested her in ways that were unforeseen. It has also precipitated further introspection from a larger than life figure.

Whatever the level of football, success is a personal and intimate topic. It is one that, in her quiet times, she has had to grapple with and redefine to her own satisfaction.

“To put it this way, I don't personally feel like I've accomplished everything I wanted to at this club,” Gielnik said quietly.

“I got to play for this club but in all fairness, I don't feel like I've been successful at this club. I haven't come here and scored a ton of goals.”

“It’s really hard to overcome the feeling of failure and that's how I've actually felt here at Bayern and although I had a massive part of the team and I work hard … I don't feel as part of the success.”

“The physical challenges are what I thought I was getting here, but I'm getting the mental challenge here as a footballer.”

On her own personal football journey, Bayern has proved to be one of the biggest challenges and the most instructive.

Gielnik’s time in Germany over the last year has become her greatest learning experience, demonstrating that perseverance and determination aren’t easily earned traits.

“I could have left on several occasions and I had offers in the transfer window to great clubs, but I thought about it and you know that’s just not me.”

Leaving and giving up and quitting it wasn’t me. I still wanted the opportunity to turn it around and see the light and to make the best of it and that's just like a part of my personality.”

“The success, I will say, is that I came here as a player that the coach wanted. He wanted me because I was that different player but then wanted me to adjust adapt to the German style football and that's not in me.”

“I had to stay true to myself.”

Emily Gielnik is not sure what her next move will be. What is certain that wherever she goes she will once again be better equipped to face it.

After all, they do say good things come to those who are wait – or a late bloomers.

Emily Gielnik plays for Melbourne Victor.page_content:
Matildas attacker Emily Gielnik has ended a nine-year association with the Brisbane Roar to sign with W-League rivals Melbourne Victory.



The 26-year-old has played for the Roar since 2009 but has opted for a change of scenery and will link up with her former coach Jeff Hopkins at Victory.



Capped 20 times for Australia, Gielnik shapes as a handy addition for a Victory outfit that hasn't qualified for the W-League finals since cross-town rivals Melbourne City entered the competition.



City have since dominated women's football in Australia while Victory have finished ninth, ninth and seventh on the ladder in those three seasons.



Emily Gielnik Jono Searle/Getty Images

"This decision to leave was most certainly not taken lightly," said Gielnik, who was born in Melbourne but moved to Brisbane at age seven.



"It was a very tough and emotional decision because orange has always been in my blood.



"I leave on a good note and I wish the staff, the players and the club all the best wishes and success for the upcoming season."



The Roar have also lost another Matildas regular in Tameka Butt, who's off to an undisclosed club.



Butt said the only reason she was departing was to take up an internship opportunity interstate.



Butt, 27, has played for the Roar for the past 10 years.

Emily Gielnik has been to a FIFA Women’s World Cup and an AFC Women’s Asian Cup and can now finally add the Olympics to her resume.

Her career is defined by perseverance and grit. Born in Melbourne, Gielnik grew up in Queensland playing a different kind of round ball sport: basketball. Injuries saw her eventually pick up football at age 12.

She played her junior football at Redlands United. Current Junior Matildas coach and Football Australia Women’s Technical Advisor Rae Dower was the Technical Director at the club when Gielnik was there.

Despite making the Queensland squad for the National Championships, Gielnik didn’t make it into the Queensland Academy of Sport (QAS) team.

She would end up in the QAS team eventually, thanks to a school trip to Canberra where she took part in a Matildas training session at the AIS under then-coach Tom Sermanni.



Sermanni suggested Gielnik to the QAS coach at the time, Jeff Hopkins, who would go on to work with Gielnik in the W-League at Brisbane Roar and Melbourne Victory.

Gielnik’s domestic career mirrored that of her national team one. A strong season in orange saw her earn the ‘super sub’ tag where she helped the Roar make a grand final. Later in 2012, she made her senior national team debut against Japan at the age of 20.

But after breaking into the national team, she spent some time away from the W-League and the Matildas.

She explored passions outside football and opened a gym, working on her own fitness and helping others. Fitness is still something that interests her as she is currently undertaking a Bachelor of Exercise Science alongside club and country teammate Clare Polkinghorne.

Gielnik worked hard to get back onto the national team radar. While she didn’t make the squad for the FIFA Women’s World Cup in Canada, she was a part of the team which qualified for the Rio Olympics the following year.



The forward scored her first national team goal in that tournament in a 9-0 win over Vietnam.

However, with plenty of talent and a small squad, Gielnik didn’t make the final cut. Instead, she travelled as an alternate player.

At the time, Gielnik said her omission left her genuinely heartbroken and described it as the biggest emotional toll football had ever taken on her.

Following on from being so close to selection, Gielnik moved to Norway before linking back up with Jeff Hopkins, this time at Melbourne Victory in the W-League.

A ‘feel good, play well’ kind of player, Gielnik returned to the national team fold and began to cement herself in the team, adding more goals to her tally.

She was selected to go to Jordan in 2018 for the AFC Women’s Asian Cup and to France in 2019 where she played in three of Australia’s four matches.

A move to German giants Bayern Munich saw her learn plenty about herself but she returned to Scandinavia and the W-League once again.



A scintillating 2020-21 season with Brisbane Roar saw Gielnik take home the golden boot before she signed for Vittsjö in Sweden. With 10 goals in 42 games for her country, the determined and dedicated Gielnik is inching ever close to half a century of caps.

A strong presence with the ability to play on the wing and more centrally, Gielnik is an invaluable asset to the Matildas in Tokyo.

Matildas attacker Emily Gielnik has ended a nine-year association with the Brisbane Roar to sign with W-League rivals Melbourne Victory.

The 26-year-old has played for the Roar since 2009 but has opted for a change of scenery and will link up with her former coach Jeff Hopkins at Victory.

Capped 20 times for Australia, Gielnik shapes as a handy addition for a Victory outfit that hasn't qualified for the W-League finals since cross-town rivals Melbourne City entered the competition.

City have since dominated women's football in Australia while Victory have finished ninth, ninth and seventh on the ladder in those three seasons.

"This decision to leave was most certainly not taken lightly," said Gielnik, who was born in Melbourne but moved to Brisbane at age seven.

"It was a very tough and emotional decision because orange has always been in my blood.

"I leave on a good note and I wish the staff, the players and the club all the best wishes and success for the upcoming season."

The Roar have also lost another Matildas regular in Tameka Butt, who's off to an undisclosed club.

Butt said the only reason she was departing was to take up an internship opportunity interstate.

Butt, 27, has played for the Roar for the past 10 years.

Emily Gielnik had a decision to make.

Less than a year out from the Women’s World Cup, the dynamic winger had two options: stay at W-League powerhouse Brisbane Roar, the club she’d joined as a teenager — or take on a new challenge.

The latter option was joining her former Roar manager Jeff Hopkins at Melbourne Victory — a club trying to return from three years in the finals wilderness.

With the pain of missing out on the Matildas’ 2015 World Cup and 2016 Olympics squads still burning fiercely, Gielnik turned her back on the comfort of home and threw herself headlong into a move interstate.

“Well to be honest, Jeff has asked me (to come to Victory) the last couple of years and it wasn’t until this year I made the move,” Gielnik told foxsports.com.au.

“I think I personally needed a bit of a challenge, a change of environment, just being around a different diverse of players and I just really needed to challenge myself in football.

“So I really feel like I just needed something new to be honest, I just didn’t want to become stagnant and be at the same place for such a long time.

“But my loyalty was really, really important to me. If I could’ve, I would’ve stayed at Brisbane for the rest of my life, the rest of my football career.

“But I really think that looking at the bigger picture in terms of the World Cup, this was a really critical move for me and … when I made the decision, it wasn’t overnight it was weeks and weeks and it was an emotional one.

“So it was a really calculated decision and I think so far for me, it’s proven to be a good one.”

Emily Gielnik and Laura Alleway celebrate (Photo by Scott Barbour/Getty Images) Source: Getty Images

Six weeks into the W-League season, Gielnik is reaping the rewards of her bold move.

Victory is sitting pretty, undefeated and outright top of the table, with the winger nominated for the PFA’s recent W-League player of the month award.

In her five appearances for Victory, Gielnik has scored one goal, assisted one, made 10 key passes, created 11 chances and provided 23 crosses.

She’s also combined beautifully with captain Natasha Dowie and star playmaker Christine Nairn, with the trio comprising one of the W-League’s most intimidating attacks.

“I think if you look at it in the perspective of a couple of weeks, it feels really good, obviously because of where we are as a team and everything,” Gielnik said.

“And me personally, I’ve already felt a lot of improvement. Most importantly, it’s just in my happiness and my mentality more than anything and I’ve got a really good support network in terms of leaving home as well.

“And obviously the staff here is great and obviously Jeff has the best intentions for me, so they’re really going above and beyond to try and cater for everything that I need football-wise. So that was really important to me in the lead up to making that decision to play for Victory.

“But obviously I already feel a really good shift and a good change for me so far but I think there’s still over half a season to go and much more improvement that I’m longing for, definitely, with the World Cup being obviously in my sights but the team being the priority of course at the moment.”

Emily Gielnik. (AAP Image/Julian Smith) Source: AAP

If moving states was one sacrifice that’s paid off, then Gielnik’s other big call was at least as significant.

The Matilda recently made the decision to end the lease on the gym she’s owned and run for several years — and admits pulling the pin on that ambition to focus solely on her football has lifted a weight off her shoulders.

“To cut a long story short — I honestly just feel like things in my life are going good and I have such a great support network and I have really, really good friends and I started to really put football first,” Gielnik said.

“My gym actually, ShredEm Fitness, that had been a lifelong dream for me that I opened before I was in the Matildas, I’ve actually just ended the lease there and decided to put all my focus into football. So that was a big thing for me.

“Purely because football is not forever and that dream job is something I can always come back to, no matter the age. So I really just want to — after years and years of sacrifice to football, I thought this was really the ultimate thing to do just to give it everything that I’ve got and enjoy every single challenge and experience because I’m obviously lucky enough to have the opportunity to be a contracted Matilda at the moment.

“So I weighed up some options and it’s not that I didn’t take it (football) seriously before, it’s just more that I’ve really made it a massive part of my life, which it has been for a long time.

“And so I think I’ve been a lot happier and a lot more focused and I’ve really dedicated a lot of my time to it off the field as well now, more from a mental aspect and keeping myself in good condition and in other parts of fitness to make sure that I’m physically good on the park.”

Emily Gielnik. (AAP Image/David Crosling) Source: AAP

This week Gielnik is set to face Brisbane for the first time since her move.

While the winger admits she’s trying not to think about the experience of facing her old club, in front of her family and friends, there are understandably some nerves.

That said, she’s had plenty of people to lean on, with fellow ex-Roar players Angie Beard, Laura Alleway and Casey Dumont among the teammates she has at Victory.

Gielnik has also thrived under Hopkins, with the Victory manager a tough, but supportive leader, and it’s clear the winger is enjoying her time in Melbourne.

While Gielnik came into a team that had struggled in recent years, it was also a club that had locked in a solid base of quality experienced and young players.

The Victory recruit highlights the culture and attitude of the group, along with the quality of the likes of Nairn and Dowie, as key reasons behind her renewed happiness and love of the game.

Emily Gielnik celebrates with Christine Nairn. (Photo by Scott Barbour/Getty Images) Source: Getty Images

“I think we’re strong all over the park and I’m not just talking performance-wise and physically and in terms of football — I’m talking in terms of team culture and the positivity and we’ve got massive, massive depth within our team,” Gielnik said.

“And I think that’s been almost the glue and something that’s been really critical this season that was really important to me ... so it’s really enjoyable and to be honest I’m really enjoying football.

“And I think players say this a lot of times, like they say they enjoy football and sometimes you can have ups and downs and football’s not (fun) all the time but I think I’ve actually started to — apart from when I was a kid — have fun with it again.”

Gielnik is certainly playing like someone enjoying her football.

The Matilda has been in fine form for both club and country, recently showcasing her ability to have an impact off the bench with a tremendous goal against Chile in Newcastle.

Australia celebrate a goal from Emily Gielnik. (Photo by Ashley Feder/Getty Images) Source: Getty Images

Gielnik’s steely resolve before and during games is hard to miss, and while she’s enjoying her football, there is a clear drive behind her relentless approach.

As a 23-year-old, Gielnik missed out on the 2015 Women’s World Cup squad — having been cut by former coach Hesterine de Reus, before Alen Stajcic took over.

Then, a year later, she missed out on the Olympics by one spot.

Now 26, and a bona fide star of the W-League, Gielnik is clearly determined not to experience that disappointment again.

“It’s a tough one because now things have been going well for the Matildas and stuff but at the end of the day I’ve never been to a World Cup or an Olympics,” Gielnik said.

“I’ve missed out shyly of the Olympics by one spot and I was training with that team during the Olympic qualifiers and everything and to pull up short and to be cut from the World Cup (hurt) and this is the opportunity of a lifetime now and I most definitely don’t want anything distracting me (and) I don’t want to waste it.

“So I’m really making sure I don’t lose focus on it and I give myself the best opportunity but I don’t lose myself as well while I’m doing that.

“So yeah, it’s a big dream of mine and it would be a goal — a life goal to be achieved to be honest — and I think W-League’s the platform for that, without putting too much pressure on myself.

“But it really is a platform for it and obviously a good opportunity for other players on a larger scale as well.”

Emily Gielnik has stood at this fork in the road before.

One path will take her one step closer to silverware. The other leads to devastation.

Gielnik knows the latter path all too well.

The Matildas forward was a member of a Brisbane Roar side that secured the premiership in 2017/18, before crashing out to eventual champions Melbourne City in a home semi-final.

It’s not an experience she's keen to re-live.

On Sunday, Gielnik will be one of the stars of a Melbourne Victory side facing Perth Glory in a semi-final, fresh off claiming its own Premiers Plate.

This time, Gielnik’s determined to be on the other side of the result.

Get every match of the 2018/19 Westfield W-League LIVE. Watch selected matches on TV and live stream the rest. SIGN UP NOW!

“With Roar it was a tough one because we played so well all season and I really felt like we were that deserving team to take the premiership and go to the grand final,” Gielnik told foxsports.com.au.

“But I mean it’s just like that typical football case isn’t it? You play well all season and then the most crucial game you’re out.

“So I think for us, obviously we’ve ticked one of our achievements off the list and that was become premiers but we want the grand final … without focusing on that I think the semi is just the most important thing right now so we’re not taking a loss for an answer for that game, really.

“Well I’m not, I’m pretty sure everyone else isn’t either.”

Emily Gielnik after the loss to Melbourne City. (Photo by Albert Perez/Getty Images) Source: Getty Images

After that semi-final last year, there was no shortage of footage of a shattered Gielnik prone on the turf.

A year on, the winger has switched clubs, taken her game to a new level and arguably gone from a super-sub to one of the best players in the W-League.

Gielnik has played a key role in Victory’s resurgence — and doesn’t want it stopping just yet.

“It’s almost the same situation to be honest. It feels a little bit different in a way, obviously because a new club, new people, new atmosphere,” she said.

“But I almost feel like it’s more of our consistent performances have felt a little bit better this year.

“And I remember that feeling, I was devastated, I actually remember lying on the ground after the game and wanting to have a bit of a tear because it just felt — not robbed — but moreso when you feel like you really deserved to be in a grand final, you really deserved to win a game and then it’s taken from you and there’s not much more you could’ve done or you’re playing the ‘what ifs’ and ‘what could’ve.’

“So I definitely don’t want that feeling again and I definitely don’t want that feeling for the rest of my teammates and our whole entire squad because I feel like we’ve worked so hard and been so consistent.

“So I really feel we are the team — without disrespecting Perth — we’re the team deserving to be in the grand final.”

Victory's Emily Gielnik and Canberra's Rachel Corsie. (AAP Image/Mick Tsikas) Source: AAP

Victory has had a less-than-ideal build-up to its semi-final, having played a catch-up game in Canberra just five days out from the clash with Perth.

The original game was postponed after lightning storms in Canberra — then, before kick-off in the replay, lightning once again delayed kick-off.

“Oh gosh, I was like ‘how has it struck twice?’ I just said ‘it’s like the Canberra gods do not want us to play this game,’” Gilenik laughed.

“I just said ‘what are the chances that this game is delayed again?’ and it is delayed.

“When we heard the thunder, we had the bad feeling — we all knew, like ‘here we go’ — we were about to head out and then it struck again and it was another 30 minutes and none of us could believe it to be honest.

“We were all just cracking up, we were just in such a daze of ‘this could be a really long night.’

“But I’d overheard that we were playing that game regardless, no matter what, whether we had to wait til midnight, we didn’t care — we wanted to play, just (get the game) out of the way, played.

“No one wants to forfeit or leave a game undecided so it was important for us to play and important for those players to get those minutes and just to see where we’re at. Even if it was a short turnaround, it was still good to get another match under our belts.”

Emily Gielnik is in fine form. (Photo by Stefan Gosatti/Getty Images) Source: Getty Images

While the game was eventually played, with a number of fringe Victory players earning crucial minutes in the 0-0 draw, Gielnik also featured for close to 60 minutes.

While the winger had one of her quieter games against Canberra, it was a rare quiet moment in a stellar first season at Victory.

“I’m pretty pleased with my form at the moment but I really am more happy than ever,” Gielnik said.

“I think I’m almost in my peak zone so hopefully I’m saving the best for last — these last two weeks.

“So (I’m) looking to put in my all time best performance for the team this weekend and then carry that confidence through to the grand final.”

Gielnik has clearly enjoyed one of the best W-League seasons of her career under Jeff Hopkins at Victory, underlining her quality as one of the league’s finest wingers.

The 26-year-old has scored four goals, recorded one assist and 19 key passes, while her 72 crosses were equal-most in the league, and she was equal-sixth in the league for shots in the regular season.

She’s also combined brilliantly with attacking maestro Christine Nairn and star striker Natasha Dowie, with the trio forming a lethal combination.

Nairn in particular has built up a strong creative partnership with Gielnik, with the pair finding each other in good pockets of space throughout the Victory attack.

Emily Gielnik and Christine Nairn have combined brilliantly. (Photo by Scott Barbour/Getty Images) Source: Getty Images

“It’s been obviously great — she’s obviously such a good player and technically a lot more advanced than I am in terms of football smartness,” Gielnik said.

“So she’s always a step ahead of me and she gives me the balls that no other teams or the other opponent doesn’t usually expect. And we’ve been on a really good wavelength and the same page recently, so I just think the good thing for me is still the best is yet to come and you know what finals football is like and that’s when you see everyone’s best football.

“So I’m super excited for that and it’s just so important and so good to have those kinds of dynamic players in midfield … so it’s been a joy and there’s nothing better than when you’ve got good players around you, I feel like it helps you and just brings confidence to the team and brings confidence to me.

“Hopefully on Sunday she can put a bit of her magic to work and hopefully I can get on the end of some.”

Similarly, Gielnik has found a good wavelength with Dowie and regularly creates golden opportunities for her Victory captain — something she credits to her past experience playing as a No.9.

Emily Gielnik and Laura Alleway celebrate. (Photo by Scott Barbour/Getty Images) Source: Getty Images

That said, when Dowie followed her shot in against Perth for the opening goal in Round 14, Gielnik wasn’t letting her striker claim it.

“It definitely hit the post and went in — I said ‘Tats, I have to claim this one,’” Gielnik said with a laugh.

“But look, I said to her ‘at the end of the day, I’m glad you were there because if it didn’t, at least you were there — but you were offside but that’s alright!’

“Obviously she’s such a prolific finisher in front of goal and I think for me as a winger instead of a No. 9 — I used to be the No. 9, I have a really good understanding of where they want the ball and now as a winger, to be fair, I almost love assisting as much as I love scoring.

“I love the joy of getting somebody else that glory so I’d love to be able to get her a few more goals up on the weekend and I’d love her to have a good game and I’d love to be a part of her having a good game.

“So hopefully we can combine on Sunday and hopefully it’s one of our best to be honest, leading into the grand final.”

Natasha Dowie (c), Christine Nairn, Jeff Hopkins, Emily Gielnik and Dani Weatherholt. (Photo by Kelly Defina/Getty Images) Source: Getty Images

Earlier this season, Gielnik detailed to foxsports.com.au the sacrifices she’d made for football — which included shutting down her long-running gym in Queensland in a bid to throw everything at her dream of making a World Cup squad.

Now, in a rich vein of form, the winger looks to have projected her name right up the Australian pecking order — and those sacrifices are bearing fruit.

“Obviously it feels like that cliche saying ‘hard work pays off’ but I feel like I have made a lot of sacrifices but I haven’t really made those sacrifices without those good people around me. There’s a lot of people behind the scenes that have dug deep in lots of different respects to help me close that gym and to get me mentally where I am today,” Gielnik said.

“And I think the change of club and the faith that I had in the change has really paid off for me, especially with where we are now, it’s even more rewarding — to (get to) where we are and where we’ve become.

“But yeah, look, I see it all as one door shuts and another one opens in other ways but I thought football is the now and with the form that I’m in and with the World Cup coming up, and I wanted to give myself the best chance (to be selected).

“So it is rewarding and it’s a nice feeling to know that the hard work is paying off and (so are) the sacrifices of me just making football my full time commitment.

“And I’m sure it’s once I’m on that plane and playing in the World Cup, that will be obviously a dream come true and it’ll all be worth it.

“But now obviously the W-League is the priority for now, winning that grand final. And then more importantly for one of my dreams, to be on that World Cup flight.”

And while that dream is an ongoing motivator, right now, Gielnik has her eyes firmly focused on the path to more W-League silverware.

And this time, she’s got no plans of a semi-final heartbreak getting in the way.

Matildas attacker Emily Gielnik has ended a nine-year association with the Brisbane Roar to sign with W-League rivals Melbourne Victory.



The 26-year-old has played for the Roar since 2009 but has opted for a change of scenery and will link up with her former coach Jeff Hopkins at Victory.



Capped 20 times for Australia, Gielnik shapes as a handy addition for a Victory outfit that hasn't qualified for the W-League finals since cross-town rivals Melbourne City entered the competition.



City have since dominated women's football in Australia while Victory have finished ninth, ninth and seventh on the ladder in those three seasons.



Emily Gielnik Jono Searle/Getty Images

"This decision to leave was most certainly not taken lightly," said Gielnik, who was born in Melbourne but moved to Brisbane at age seven.



"It was a very tough and emotional decision because orange has always been in my blood.



"I leave on a good note and I wish the staff, the players and the club all the best wishes and success for the upcoming season."



The Roar have also lost another Matildas regular in Tameka Butt, who's off to an undisclosed club.



Butt said the only reason she was departing was to take up an internship opportunity interstate.



Butt, 27, has played for the Roar for the past 10 years.

Upbeat Melbourne Victory star Emily Gielnik admitted carrying the confidence from her starring Matildas super sub role in the win over Chile into Friday night’s derby win.

Gielnik’s player-of-the-match performance, which included a goal in the 2-0 win at AAMI Park, has inspired Victory’s best start to a W-League season and the attacker says teams should fear them.

Joining Victory after nine years at Brisbane Roar, Gielnik’s move has paid off with Matildas coach Alen Stajcic rewarding her with international minutes ahead of next year’s World Cup.

Gielnik is relishing her soccer for club and country and wants to entertain.

Camera Icon Emily Gielnik celebrates with Christine Nairn after scoring a goal. Pic: Getty Images Credit: Getty Images

“I got 32 minutes (for the Matildas) — not that I’m counting or anything, but I was pretty happy with that. It was 20-something minutes more than the last game,’’ Gielnik said.

“I was pretty happy and honestly I haven’t scored for my country for a really long time. I felt really good out there and yeah, I wish that was a little bit longer.

“I was so happy to score (for Victory) obviously ... I just want to keep playing. I wanted to get another goal to be honest, I wanted a third.

“I want to push that this season, that we give people that travel and come out to watch us, I want us to entertain and push forward right to the 95th minute.”

Victory plays W-League heavyweights Sydney FC next week with Gielnik hoping their rich form continues, adding the City win was a huge boost after the local rivals have dominated the league with three straight titles.

“I actually stood up and said there’s a lot of talk and media and few articles about how we were the underdogs and I said the pressure was all on City,’’ she said,

“I love being on the underdog, so it was really important that we came together and showed that we are a good side.

“Sydney for me is just another team. We need to really put the pressure off ourselves and the other teams that should be a bit scared of us from now on.

“I really think we’ve got the capabilities within our team and that we should worry less about other teams and more about how we’re going to play.”

Melbourne Victory have bolstered their W-League title ambitions and won bragging rights with a 2-0 dismissal in their derby against Melbourne City.

Jeff Hopkins’ side sit on top of the ladder after Elise Kellond-Knight’s own goal and Emily Gielnik’s breakaway finish at AAMI Park on Friday night.

Despite City’s wealth of internationals, Victory looked the more polished outfit and remarkably so after a slice of pre-match drama.

Traffic delayed the arrival of Matildas defender Laura Alleway and youth international Kyra Cooney-Cross to just minutes before kick-off.

Alleway landed in the nick of time, warming up by herself and being thrust into action but Cooney-Cross had to watch from the stands.

“We had probably the worst preparation we’ve had all season with the traffic,” Hopkins said.

“It’s where the girls are at the moment with their spirit. They didn’t let anything affect them.”

Thankfully for Cooney-Cross, her side and replacement midfielder MelindaJ Barbieri performed admirably in the defeat of the three-time champions.

Christine Nairn pulled the strings in midfield, while Victory’s entire back four and goalkeeper Casey Dumont were superb.

The contest was on from the first whistle but it took almost half an hour before the first serious chance.

City’s Yukari Kinga should have scored at the back post from Tameka Butt’s fine cross but headed over.

Victory first warmed into the contest and then made them pay. Gielnik might have added to her goal scored on Matildas duty on Tuesday in Australia’s 5-0 rout of Chile but got her outside-of-the-boot shot was off target.

Victory’s pressure told on 31 minutes when Nairn’s superb cross had Kellond- Knight in all sorts.

Under pressure from Natasha Dowie, the veteran headed past her Matildas’ teammate Lydia Williams in goal to give Victory a worthy lead. After the break, Dumont pulled off a fingertip save to deny Butt’s strike from City’s best move of the night.

Natasha Dowie, Melina Ayres, Dani Weatherholt, Christine Nairn, Emily Gielnik of the Victory and their teammates celebrate. (Photo by Scott Barbour/Getty Images) Source: Getty Images

As City pushed women forward for an equaliser, Victory caught them cold.

Dowie found Gielnik rampaging down the right, who ran clear and delivered a textbook finish on 65 minutes to seal the contest.

The loss was City coach Rado Vidosic’s second in three matches as the expansion club slumped to their worst start since joining the competition.

“I thought we controlled the game quite a lot to be honest,” he said.

“But we were missing five players from our starting eleven ... I don’t think any W-League team missing three defenders would be able to compete the way we did.”

Emily Gielnik also plays for Bayern Muni.page_content:
The 27-year-old leaves Melbourne Victory to link up with the iconic club who play in the Frauen-Bundesliga, the top division in Germany.





Gielnik, who has played 31 times for the national team, said the move was a dream come to.





"I'm excited. It is the dream of every footballer to play for a top club like Bayern Munich. As a striker, I now want to score as many goals as I can for my new club," she told the Bayern Munich website.





"I want to win the Bundesliga and the Champions League with this great team. These are big goals, I know, but that's exactly what I'm going to fight for and give everything."







The Aussie clearly impressed Bayern Munich's hierarchy with her FIFA Women's World Cup performances in France.





"We are happy that Emily has decided for Bayern. She has a good physique and speed and can play in the offensive area on all positions. This type of player was missing us in the squad," Bayern head coach Jens Scheuer said.





"We've been watching Emily for a while. At the 2019 World Cup, she once again came to the fore with the Australian national team, so we wanted to make a commitment after the opportunity arose."

“Basketball was my first love in sport - my height [she is six foot] was useful but I was just a go-getter, I had so much energy back then, I was just running everyone down,” she said. “I was playing at a high level when I was younger and I’d also played rugby league with the boys through school and made it to the next level with the district team - I scored a few tries, but the boys in there were absolutely huge, so district level was the last stop for me. But football was definitely the right choice.

“My Mum didn’t want me playing football initially, she thought basketball was a safer option, I loved it, but then it became too much once I played football as well at the age of 12, I had to decide, and football took over.”

A good choice. Gielnik's gilded, and nomadic, career has taken her to the top flights in Canada, Japan, Norway, Sweden and Germany - where she played for Bayern Munich - as well as Australia. Now she intends to make Villa a more permanent home.

“That’s been a personal preference of mine, I’ve always only signed a one-year contract,” Gielnik added. “This is the first year where I’ve signed a 1+1. That’s a big shift for me, which means I’ve had a good feeling about this club.

“I’ve wanted to really experience all the different styles of football and the different cultures, and where I can develop in different countries, so I’m pretty fortunate that I’ve been around the world. That was my decision, and I’m glad I’ve done it that way, I’ve definitely grown from having been in all those situations, and now I’ve landed here.”

Yet, Gielnik is not a Women’s Super League debutant. Her goal for Villa at Brighton was her first in the WSL for more than nine years, since she netted for Liverpool in a 3-3 draw away at Notts County in 2012. She spent one season on Merseyside, but knows she returns now transformed as a player, and to a completely changed league.

“It was always on my radar, to end up back in the WSL, but I don’t really want to count it as being in the WSL 10 years ago, because that was not the league it is now. The WSL has come on leaps and bounds. Back then with Liverpool, I was only training twice a week, so I’m kind of treating this as my first time here."

Life at Villa - who host league leaders Arsenal on Saturday - is going well so far, as they have seven points from their opening three goals, boosted by her strike at Brighton, a calm finish into the corner after being played through one-on-one.

“Getting the winner and getting my first goal, I felt I kind of needed to get that one out of the way," she said. "Those first few games, you want to start strong and get some points on the board early.”

The English league looks set to suit Gielnik's strong, quick and clinical style. “I wouldn’t say I’m the most technical striker but I’m a very counter-attacking, ball-in-behind, fast-paced, off-the-shoulder kind of player," she added. "I’m not much of a dribbler, but I love on the end of crosses and I also love delivering crosses, breaking the lines and getting in behind.”

Her move to Villa was one that almost didn’t happen, after multiple approaches from the West Midlands club, before she was ultimately persuaded to move on September’s deadline day after a short spell with Swedish top-tier side Vittsjo GIK.

Gielnik explained: “I’d had several conversations with my agent, just telling him to politely decline any others that had come through during the Olympics, so there were a few knock-backs already to Carla [Ward], but she was pretty persistent and that actually worked on me in the end because I actually needed a change. Carla had belief in me and wants me to progress. I told her how adamant I am to improve and get better and she is willing to provide that.

“The question I asked Carla was just about the team: Is it good people and is it a good environment? Those were the two big things for me. After a few phone calls, it turned out to be the right thing for me to do. Now I’ve landed here so hopefully I can gain some consistency here at this club and lead myself into the 2023 World Cup.”

Emily Gielnik’s Bayern Munich kept up with the pace in the Frauen-Bundesliga by recording a 3-1 win against Potsdam.

The 31-cap Westfield Matilda was handed a starting role for the German giants following her goalscoring efforts in the midweek UEFA Women’s Champions League victory against Kazakhstan side BIIK Kazygurt.

And the 2018-19 Frauen-Bundesliga champions made it three on the stroke of half-time when Jovana Damnjanovic coverted from the penalty spot.

Emily Gielnik helped Bayern Munich secure three points in their final match before the winter break in Germany’s Frauen Bundesliga.

The Reds edged FFC Frankfurt 3-2 on the road at the Stadion am Brentanobad thanks to Melanie Lupolz’s 88th-minute winner.

Westfield Matildas attacker Gielnik came on as a 78th-minute substitute with the match locked at 2-2 to help her side take the points back to Bavaria on Saturday (AEDT).

Laura Freigang had given the home side the advantage on nine minutes but Netherlands international Lineth Beerensteyn equalised for the visitors on 29 minutes.

Carolin Simon tipped the match in Bayern’s favour three minutes after half-time but Freigang squared it back up in the 72nd minute.

Gielnik was sent on in place of Linda Dallmann with the match hanging in the balance, and Lupolz struck the winner two minutes from time.

The win keeps Bayern third in the Frauen Bundesliga ladder, six points behind leaders Wolfsburg and three back from Hoffenheim.

German football takes a break over the winter months, with Bayern returning with an away match against Bayern Leverkusen on 16 February 2020.

Lisa De Vanna featured in Fiorentina’s 4-0 win against Inter Milan in Italy’s Serie A on Sunday (AEDT).

Tatiana Bonetti hit a hat-trick and Caterina Fracaros scored an own goal to clinch a resounding win for the second-placed side.

De Vanna was introduced from the bench for Spanish forward Paloma Lazaro in the 73rd minute as La Viola wrapped up the win.

The Italian league breaks until 11 January, with Fiorentina six points behind top of the table Juventus.

Bayern Munich Frauen have announced the signing of Emily Gielnik from the Melbourne Victory in Australia. The length of the contract was not announced. The big forward joins a ever-growing squad as Bayern continue their rebuild with trophies on their mind.

Gielnik is ready to get going.

“I’m excited. It is the dream of every footballer to play for a top club like Bayern Munich. As a striker, I now want to score as many goals as I can for my new club. I want to win the Bundesliga and the Champions League with this great team. These are big goals, I know, but that’s exactly what I’m going to fight for and give everything.”

This isn’t Gielnik’s first European club. Previously in her career, she’s suited up for Liveprool in England and Avaldsnes in Norway. However, as The Women’s Game points out, Gielnik is one of the more high-profile Matildas players to make the move to Europe now. World star Sam Kerr has been rumored for a few months now to be making a high dollar move to England, but that hasn’t materialized yet. However, it does show that Europe is becoming another destination for great players that have long gone to the United States.

She’ll wear the number 15 in Munich.

Emily Gielnik has got off to a winning start with her new German club Bayern Munich overnight.

In her first start for the club, Bayern thrashed Eintracht Frankfurt 5-0 in the opening round of the DFB Pokal Women (German Cup.

Starting in attack, Gielnik had a hand in Simone Boye’s first-half goal to help Bayern shoot to a 2-0 lead inside 18 minutes.

The 27-year-old, who has also played for Liverpool in England, played just over an hour before she was substituted to a warm ovation from the fans.

Gielnik last month signed a one-year deal with Bayern after helping Melbourne Victory win their premiership in the Westfield W-League in 2018/19.

Bayern’s next match is a UEFA Women’s Champions League trip to Sweden to play Goteborg on Thursday (AEST).

They then turn their attention back to Frauen Bundesliga action as they host Bayer Leverkusen next weekend.



In Norway’s Toppserien, there was contrasting fortunes for a couple of Westfield Matildas midfielders.

Aivi Luik’s Avaldsness consolidated their spot in the top six with a resounding 3-0 win away at Fart.

But it was a tough outing for Tameka Butt’s Klepp, who lost 4-0 at Valerenga.

Melbourne Victory skipper Natasha Dowie was on the scoresheet for Valerenga, who are in third spot, just ahead of Butt’s Klepp (fourth).

Meanwhile in Spain, Alex Chidiac’s Atletico Madrid made a winning start to their La Liga Femenina title defence with a 1-0 win over Sporting De Huelva.

Chidiac wasn’t involved in Atletico’s matchday squad.

It's a dominant start for the Bavarians in the domestic cup, moving on with an 8-0 win on aggregate.

Coming into a busy beginning to the season, Bayern are competing across three competitions which should create plenty of opportunities for Gielnik. The next chance for the Aussie to have a hit-out will be their UEFA Champions League clash against Swedish giants Goteborg.

Gielnik started and played the first 65 minutes, playing a role in multiple goals before her withdrawal. The club congratulated her performance on Twitter.

She then took to Instagram to praise the start to life in Germany.
